stem: A 34-year-old client with bipolar disorder is being evaluated after 2 weeks on Lithium Carbonate. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Routine follow-up for medication titration.
Background: Diagnosed with Bipolar I. Started Lithium 300mg TID.
Assessment: Client reports mild thirst, frequent urination, and 'slight shaking' in the hands.
Recommendation: Check serum level and electrolyte balance.

tabs.title: Lithium Trough & Side Effect Inventory
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingSeverity
Serum Lithium Level0.9 mEq/LTherapeutic (Target 0.6-1.2)
Tremor TypeFine, rapid; noticeable when writingGrade 1 (Expected)
GastrointestinalOccasional mild nausea but eats mealsMild (Expected)

tabs.title: Metabolic Panel
tabs.content: Serum Sodium: 138 mEq/L (Normal). BUN: 14 mg/dL. Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL.

conditionOptions.text: Therapeutic Lithium Levels with Expected Side Effects

actionOptions.text: Reassure the client that mild tremors and thirst are common initially
Administer the next scheduled 300mg dose of Lithium
Hold the dose and prepare for emergency hemodialysis
Instruct the client to significantly reduce sodium intake

parameterOptions.text: Serum Lithium levels drawn 12 hours after the last dose (Trough)
Presence of coarse tremors or slurred speech (Toxic signs)

rationale.correct: The client's lithium level of 0.9 mEq/L is within the therapeutic range (0.6-1.2) (c2). Mild fine tremors, thirst, and nausea are expected side effects that often occur at the beginning of therapy. The nurse should reassure the client (a1) and continue the medication as prescribed (a2). Monitoring trough levels (p1) and fluid intake/hydration (p2) are critical for preventing toxicity.
clinicalPearls: Fine tremors = Normal. Coarse tremors = Toxicity.
Lithium is a salt; if sodium is restricted, lithium levels will rise dangerously.

questionTrap.trap: Holding the dose for a therapeutic level because of 'shaking'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Differentiate between 'Fine' (Normal) and 'Coarse' (Toxic). Fine tremors do not require holding the medication.

mnemonic.title: Lithium Level
mnemonic.expansion: L-Long-term (Bipolar). I-Inverse to Sodium. T-Therapeutic (0.6-1.2). H-Hand tremors (Fine is fine).
